description.narrative: The humanitarian situation in Somalia remains critical due to the ongoing impacts of drought, conflict, locust infestation and the COVID 19 pandemic which has created a global health emergency. In the later part of 2020 up until the recent months of 2021, most parts of the country have been experiencing moderate to severe drought conditions. This drought conditions were triggered by consecutive seasons of below-average rainfall including the below average October to December 2020 Deyr rainfall season, the above average temperatures during the January to March 2021 harsh Jilaal/dry season as well as the significantly below average April to June Gu/longrains which was delayed. The worst affected region is the Jubaland state which has been experiencing severe drought conditions thathas placed thousands of pastoralist households under acute water stress. Significant pasture degradation and water shortages have been reported in many areas of Jubaland/South Central Somalia due to two consecutive seasons of significantly below average rainfall.Crops have failed; substantial livestock mortality is occurring and prices of basic food commodities have increased in the recent months. Currently, water shortages are alarming in the Afmadow and Badhaade districts of the lower Juba region thus affecting a high number of already vulnerable people many of whom are IDPs, returnees and vulnerable pastoralists. Pastoralist families across the districts are uprooting their lives and moving in search of water and pasture for their animals, particularly in the areas bordering Kenya. There have been reports of increased prices of water in most of these districts. A quick market spot check conducted on key water points in Afmadow and Badhaade towns by WASDA team revealed that the average price of a 20- litter jerry can of water in the main water points in these towns was Som. Shs 8,000, an equivalent of USD 0.3. Available water is additionally often contaminated and highly saline in these areas as confirmed by WASDA and Oxfam’s WASH coordinator. The Somalia Food Security Cluster as of 18th October2021 confirms that half of Somalia is still experiencing serious drought conditions (moderate to severe drought with water shortages and livestock losses), with the worst impacts being felt in Jubaland, South West State, Galmudug and areas of Puntland. The Deyr seasonal rainfall is expected to be below average, with depressed rains not going to be effective in mitigating drought conditions. It is estimated that 12,700 households in both districts are affected by water shortages. The local authorities have issued an appealletter to humanitarian partners to support affected families with lifesaving assistance. In rural villages it is reported that almost all water sources have dried up, with a significant number of shallow wells and strategic boreholes yielding low water, causing mass concentration of livestock with long hours of queuing at the water sources. Further information emanating from the District Commissioner’s office (Afmadow) also highlighted that many pastoral communities from the neighboring towns in Middle Juba region (controlled by Al-Shabaab) who migrated with their livestock as a result of the devastating drought have gradually settled in Afmadow town,putting extra pressure on the few existing hand-dug shallow wells which are now the only remaining sources of water. WASDA as one of the few actors in Jubaland having sustained access and relationships with the affected communities have just completed a 30-day NEXUS/DRA-funded anticipatory emergency water trucking response. Other agencies and local communities are undertaking similar small scale water trucking activities. It is against this background that WASDA is proposing to undertake an emergency Livelihood, WASH and protection interventions in Afmadow and Badhaade districts of Lower Juba that will meet the immediate food security and livelihood, WASH and protection needs of vulnerable populations affected by drought. The specific activities to be undertaken under the food security and livelihood (FSL) will be 1) cash based interventions in the form of un-conditional cash transfers to improve purchasing power and food access for vulnerable pastoralist households, 2) The activities under the WASH intervention will include provision of safe drinking water (water trucking, fuel subsidy to borehole, water treatment chemicals), hygiene promotion (hygiene kits distribution, sanitation and hygiene campaign) and 3) protection activities include awareness creation on GBV prevention, provision of dignity kits, radio spot messaging on GBV prevention awareness campaigns and referral of GBV cases to relevant GBV service providers.

participating-org.narrative: WASDA was established as a nongovernmental in Somalia in 2001. The organisation strives to supplement the efforts of governments and other development stakeholders in addressing developmental challenges in the Horn of Africa. WASDA is currently implementing development initiatives in North-Eastern Kenya and parts of Southern Somalia. WASDA has been working with pastoral communities in North-Eastern Kenya and Southern Somalia for 23 years. The organisation has, in the process, gained and built a wealth of experience and knowledge that informs its programming. It utilises limited resources to change the lives of millions of people in its geographical areas of operation. In the last 23 years, WASDA has reached over 1.5 million people with livelihood, food security; water; sanitation and hygiene; health and nutrition; education and emergency humanitarian support. VISION Empowered communities in the Horn of Africa that are resilient, innovative and peaceful MISSION To mobilize and engage communities and other stakeholders in creating strategic partnerships for sustainable management of the environment, water resources, livelihoods, and education and public health services in the Horn of Africa.
